title: US President sanctions Jewish settlers involved in violence against Palestinians - Teller Report
text: President Biden of the United States has signed an executive order that allows sanctions to be imposed on those responsible for a series of violence committed by extremist Jewish settlers in the West Bank of Palestine. According to OCHA (United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs), since military conflict between Israel and the Islamic group Hamas began in the Gaza Strip last October, violence against Palestinians by Jewish settlers has increased in the West Bank as well. . In response, President Biden issued an executive order on the 1st that would allow sanctions to be imposed on those involved in acts of violence, stating that ``violence, forced displacement, and destruction by extremist settlers has reached intolerable levels.'' I signed it. If you are subject to sanctions, your assets in the United States will be frozen and you will not be able to do business with Americans. Following the signing of the presidential order, the U.S. State Department announced sanctions against four people allegedly involved in attacks on residents and arson of buildings in the West Bank. Last December, the US government restricted the issuance of visas to people involved in acts of violence, and this time it has further strengthened its response. President Biden has previously criticized violence committed by Jewish settlers and has expressed his concerns directly to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

author: Mirage News
title: Innovative clay trial improves estuary water quality | Mirage News
text: - Healthy Estuaries WA trial helping to reduce algal blooms in the Peel-Harvey estuary catchment - Innovative clay-based treatment improves water quality by locking up excess phosphorus, which can fuel potentially harmful algae - Early results show the clay successfully reduces phosphorus concentrations in the treated water by up to 95 per cent An innovative new trial is helping to improve water quality in the Peel-Harvey estuary catchment by reducing the nutrients that fuel algal growth. Scientists from Healthy Estuaries WA have applied a specially manufactured clay-based treatment to a drain in the catchment of the Peel-Harvey estuary (Bindjareb Djilba). The clay successfully bound up to 95 per cent of phosphorus at the treatment site, preventing it from fuelling algal growth in the downstream waterways. Many of our waterways like the Serpentine River (Waangaamaap Bilya) can receive excess phosphorus from fertiliser use in their catchment, potentially causing algal growth that can lead to fish kills and adverse human health impacts. The Department of Water and Environmental Regulation (DWER) has been working on a novel clay known as Hydrotalcite clay, or HT-clay. It is made from a natural bentonite clay modified with hydrotalcite: a phosphorus binding mineral. The manufacturing process involves mixing several raw ingredients together, causing chemical reactions where the clay becomes coated in the phosphorus binding material. The application of the clay to reduce phosphorus concentrations in the waterways complements ongoing work through Healthy Estuaries WA in the catchment. This work with farmers is reducing the amount of fertiliser applied to farms, preventing loss of further nutrients to the waterways. The clay production and distribution have been funded by the State Government's Bindjareb Djilba Protection Plan and Healthy Estuaries WA program. Healthy Estuaries WA is a $25 million State Government commitment, which focuses on improving the health of Peel-Harvey estuary, Leschenault Estuary, Vasse-Geographe waterways, Hardy Inlet, Wilson Inlet, Torbay Inlet and Oyster Harbour. The Healthy Estuaries WA program uses the latest science to monitor and manage our precious waterways, alongside successful collaborative projects involving community, scientists, farmers, government and industry. For further updates on important Healthy Estuaries work underway, visit [facebook.com/healthyestuarieswa](https://www.facebook.com/healthyestuarieswa/) As stated by Water Minister Simone McGurk: "The phosphorus binding clay is a Western Australian invention and demonstrates the innovative new approaches our State Government is taking to look after the health of our precious waterways. "The groundbreaking research in the Peel-Harvey estuary complements the important work Healthy Estuaries WA is doing to reduce the amount of fertiliser applied to farms. "While there is much work happening in the catchment to reduce nutrient inputs for the future, this is showing promising signs of how to address the high levels of nutrients that are polluting some of our waterways right now." Comments attributed to Mandurah MLA David Templeman: "We know the Peel-Harvey estuary (Bindjareb Djilba) is the heart of our community in Mandurah, and we need to address water quality issues so that our waterways can continue to be the lifeblood of our community for generations to come. "This trial demonstrates that there are many tools available to us to improve water quality, and we need to make use of them all to achieve significant nutrient reductions for the Peel-Harvey estuary." Comments attributed to Dawesville MLA Lisa Munday: "Our precious waterways are so important for the region and that's why it's vital we do everything we can to safeguard them and keep them healthy. "It's fantastic to see the team at Healthy Estuaries WA putting innovation into action and achieving promising results." [here](/innovative-clay-trial-improves-estuary-water-1175469/).

author: Mahnoor Jehangir
title: Controversial Group Mend Trains UK Public Bodies Amid Extremism Concerns
text:
Imagine the halls of British institutions, where officers and staff are keenly learning about Islamophobia, its impact, and strategies to combat it. The organization at the helm, Mend, known for its contentious views and connections, has stepped into the spotlight, raising eyebrows and questions about the fine line between education and influence. As a journalist, I've delved into the intricacies of this situation, uncovering the layers that make up this complex narrative.
Engagement with Controversy
Since October 7, Mend has been at the forefront, providing Islamophobia training to a wide range of British institutions, from the
British Transport Police and South Wales Police to universities and NHS staff. This engagement has sparked a debate, given Mend's history of defending jihadists and advocating for a 'Palestinian victory,' which has been criticized by figures like Sir William Shawcross in his review of Prevent. Shawcross particularly pointed out Mend's track record of working alongside extremists and its potential to undermine counter-extremism efforts.
The Training's Reach and Criticism
The extent of Mend's influence is significant, having provided courses to hundreds of public sector staff on combating Islamophobia. However, this has not come without its critics. The organization's association with figures who have been linked to extremist ideologies and actions raises a red flag for many. The CEO of Mend, Azhar Qayum, has been reported to give speeches advocating for Palestinian victory, a stance that further complicates Mend's position within the realm of public training programs. Critics argue that such connections and ideologies being imparted to public sector employees could potentially skew perceptions and actions in a manner that is not conducive to unbiased public service.
The Broader Implications
The partnership between Mend and various British public institutions opens up a broader conversation about the vulnerability of Britain's public sector to extremist influence. It begs the question of the appropriateness of such partnerships and the potential long-term implications for counter-extremism strategies. The case of Mend also highlights the challenges in balancing the fight against Islamophobia with the need to ensure that those leading the charge do not carry controversial or extremist baggage. As institutions strive to educate their staff and promote inclusivity, the choice of partners for such important training becomes ever more crucial.
In light of these developments, the narrative surrounding Mend's involvement with British institutions underscores the complexities of addressing Islamophobia while safeguarding against extremist influences. It is a delicate balance, one that requires ongoing scrutiny and reflection to ensure that the goals of inclusivity and safety are both met without compromise. As readers, it's essential to understand the multifaceted nature of these issues, recognizing that the path to combating hate and extremism is fraught with challenges that demand careful consideration and action.

author: Lennart Schwenck
title: „Geschmacklos": Müller-Produkt stößt Kundin auf - Drogeriemarkt zieht Konsequenzen
text:
„Geschmacklos“: Müller-Produkt stößt Kundin auf – Drogeriemarkt zieht Konsequenzen
Eine Müller-Kundin findet ein anzügliches Modellbau-Set in der Spielwarenabteilung. Der Drogeriemarkt reagiert prompt. Auch der Hersteller äußert sich.
München – Ein unscheinbares Modellbau-Set erregt aktuell viel Aufsehen: Das Figuren-Set „Voyeure“ der Firma NOCH aus Wangen im Allgäu zeigt halbnackte Frauen, einen Mann mit Fernglas – und ein Kind, das sich die Augen zuhält. Es ist Teil einer Produktreihe für Modelleisenbahn-Landschaften. Das eigentlich unauffällige Set aus dem Standardsortiment wurde zum Zentrum einer hitzigen Debatte über Geschmack, Ethik und die Grenzen der Miniaturdarstellung.
Auslöser für den Wirbel war eine Beschwerde: Christine B. entdeckte das Set in der Spielwarenabteilung einer Müller-Filiale in München. Gegenüber Bild kritisierte sie: „Hier wird Voyeurismus verharmlost und Kindern als harmlose Unterhaltung vermittelt.“ Für sie sei das „nicht nur geschmacklos, sondern auch höchst verantwortungslos.“
Figuren-Set verschwindet nach Beschwerde von Kundin aus dem Müller-Sortiment
Der Drogeriemarkt Müller reagierte prompt. Ein Sprecher des Unternehmens erklärte gegenüber der BILD-Zeitung: „Beim Handelskonzern Müller legen wir größten Wert auf ein verantwortungsvolles und familienfreundliches Sortiment. […] Die betreffenden Artikel wurden umgehend entfernt.“ Man bedaure den Vorfall sehr und prüfe derzeit, wie ähnliche Fehler in Zukunft vermieden werden könnten. Das Figuren-Set ist mittlerweile aus dem Sortiment und Online-Handel entfernt worden.
Die Firma Noch GmbH, ein traditionsreiches Familienunternehmen mit 114-jähriger Geschichte und europäischer Marktführerschaft im Bereich Modellbauzubehör, zeigt sich angesichts der Empörung gelassen. Geschäftsführer Rainer Noch erklärte gegenüber dem SWR: „Die Verkaufszahlen haben am Dienstagmorgen schon deutlich angezogen.“ Er rechne damit, dass das Set bald ausverkauft sein werde. Dass gerade dieses Figuren-Set für Diskussionen sorgt, verwundert Noch: „Die Realität kennt keine Tabus, und um ein wirklichkeitsnahes Abbild zu schaffen, ist es notwendig, auch jene Aspekte darzustellen, die zum menschlichen Leben gehören.“ Das Set sei seit Jahren im Sortiment und habe bislang kaum Kritik ausgelöst.
Hersteller äußert sich: „Wir wollen das Leben in all seinen Facetten darstellen“
Das Set „Voyeure“ ist Teil einer Linie von Miniaturfiguren, mit denen Noch laut eigener Website „humorvolle oder ungewöhnliche Szenen“ darstellen will. Im Online-Shop wird es als geeignet für „erotische Szenen in Ihrer Modelllandschaftsgestaltung“ beworben. Die Figuren sind übliche Miniaturfiguren, wie man sie zum Beispiel aus dem Miniaturwunderland in Hamburg kennt. Während kritische Stimmen, wie die von Christine B., das Set als sexualisierte Darstellung mit problematischer Botschaft einstufen, betont der Hersteller seine künstlerische und realitätsnahe Freiheit. „Wir wollen das Leben in all seinen Facetten darstellen,“ sagte Rainer Noch gegenüber dem SWR.
Die Aufmerksamkeit ist für das Unternehmen aus dem Allgäu offenbar kein Nachteil. Bereits auf der Spielwarenmesse in Nürnberg präsentierte die Noch GmbH eine neue Linie namens „Funny-Scenes“, die Sets mit Bezeichnungen wie „Saufbrüder“, „Seitensprung“ oder „Straßenstrich“ umfasst. Diese sollen ab Oktober im Handel erhältlich sein. Das, was der eine lustig findet, dem anderen sauer aufstößt, ist keine Seltenheit. So erhiet etwa auch ein Mafia-Brettspiel heftigen Gegenwind. (ls)
